cmCourseInfo.description: This is the language course to take if you have had no previous experience of the German language. The emphasis is on comprehension, speaking, reading, writing, vocabulary and basic grammar. This course can be counted towards all programs in German. Note: Students with any previous knowledge of German are REQUIRED to take a placement test offered at the department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to German
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Senior high school German or equivalent. Note: Students with any previous knowledge of German are required to take a placement test offered at the department.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

GER100Y is a full-year German language course for absolute beginners. Students with any previous knowledge should email german.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca to take the placement test.

There are no tutorials for GER100Y, but there is a co-curricular (non-mandatory) tutorial called the Multilingual German Lab (MGL). Information about MGL will be announced via email after the semester begins.

cmCourseInfo.description: This is the language course to take if you have had no previous experience of the German language. The emphasis is on comprehension, speaking, reading, writing, vocabulary and basic grammar. This course can be counted towards all programs in German. Note: Students with any previous knowledge of German are REQUIRED to take a placement test offered at the department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to German

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is intended for students with some prior knowledge of German. It is equivalent to the Spring Term of GER100Y1. The emphasis is on comprehension, speaking, reading, writing, vocabulary and basic grammar.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to German b
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Senior high school German or equivalent. GER100Y1.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

GER101H is the second half of GER100Y, offered in the winter term. Students placed in GER101 must be manually added to the course by the department. Enrollment on ACORN is not available. 

To take the placement test, please email german.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course taught in English is intended for students who are unfamiliar with German culture. It examines historical, political and cultural developments in Germany from about 1871 to the present focusing on literary and non-literary texts. (Note: This course is required for the major and specialist program; it should be taken within the first two years.)
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to German Culture (E)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course is taught in English.

Are you curious about German culture? What comes to your mind when you think of things German? Beer and sausages, high-performance cars, the Black Forest, or a mania for efficiency? This course moves beyond these cultural stereotypes and offers a kaleidoscopic view of German culture in its varied manifestations, be it in the form of cultural artifacts, great works of literature, family histories, or big ideas. We will explore world-shaping ideas and inventions from the Reformation and the Gutenberg Press to Bauhaus and modern industrial design, the connection between the Grimm Brothers’ fairy tales and their nation-building efforts, German fantasies about Indigenous North America and the longing for untouched nature, and personal narratives that grapple with the Nazi past and divided Germany. Ideal for students from across the disciplines, the course invites you to think critically about what constitutes German culture while expanding your cross-cultural understanding and global perspective. (No knowledge of German required.)

cmCourseInfo.description: Vampires are among the most fascinating figures of popular culture. Since Bram Stoker’s Dracula (1897) – and, in fact, well before that – they have been haunting the human imagination in various shapes and forms. This course examines the figure of the vampire as a potent cultural metaphor in the German context and beyond, showing how every age embraces the vampires it needs and gets the vampires it deserves. The goal is to teach students to reflect critically and independently on issues of self and society and to develop a structured approach to critical thinking in general. All readings and class discussions will be in English. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Our Vampires, Ourselves (E)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

First year foundation course, taught in English.

This course explores vampires as mirrors of our own experiences. With a syllabus that spans Dracula, Carmilla, True Blood, Twilight, and more, students dive deep into the lasting allure of these immortal beings.

Read more about this course in the A&S News.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course continues the work done in GER100Y1 / GER101H1. It further expands on basic grammar and vocabulary, practice in comprehension, composition, and conversation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate German 1
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: GER100Y1/GER101H1 or German placement test, Senior high school German or equivalent

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

GER201H is the second half of GER200Y, offered in the winter term. Students placed in GER201 must be manually added to the course by the department. Enrollment on ACORN is not available. 

To take the placement test, please email german.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers a transition from the language courses to the topic courses on the 300-level. It introduces students to German literature and provides them with working methods and analytical tools relevant for the study of German literary texts in the original German. Note: This course is required for the major program. It should be taken as early as possible, and cannot be taken after completion of GER300Y1 or GER301H1. This course is the prerequisite course for 300-level topic courses in German.
cmCourseInfo.title: Masterpieces of German Literature 1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course is taught in German.

A required course for the German major program and pre-requisite course for most of the 300-level topic GER courses. 

GER205 cannot be taken after completion of GER300Y/301H.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines German cinema against the backdrop of European film history. European films share common references points anchored in the cataclysms of two world wars, and have also negotiated analogous postwar transformations in family life, urbanization, the regional and the national, cultural identity, labour relations, post-socialist societies, and state security. A comparative approach enables examination of what binds German cinema to European cinema – shared histories and political concerns--as well as what is nationally unique and distinctive. By matching select films with readings from social theory, cultural studies, and film studies, we will compare and contrast these socio-historical concerns while also attending to the medium specificities of film style, aesthetics, and narrative form.
cmCourseInfo.title: German and European Cinema (E)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course is taught in English. Open to all students.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces Yiddish language, literature, music, theater, and cinema through interactive multi-media seminars, designed to build proficiency in reading, writing and comprehending. No prior knowledge of Yiddish is required.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary Yiddish 1

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is the continuation of GER261H1, Elementary Yiddish 1. While learning the language the course will also introduce students to Yiddish literature & culture, providing a greater understanding of the historical and contemporary, religious and secular communities that speak and spoke this language.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary Yiddish 2

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to basic concepts and vocabulary necessary for the German business context. All the language skills (reading, writing, listening, and speaking) will be practiced in appropriate business contexts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Business German

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course is taught in German. 
PRE-/CO-REQUISITE: GER 200Y/201H or placement test

To take the placement test, please email german.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: The movement of cultural products, material goods, capital, people, ideas, and information across national borders has resulted in a new quality of global interdependency. The course explores the contemporary character of globalization patterns and problems as they bear on German-speaking contexts. Readings in globalization history and theory.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Issues - German Contexts (E)
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: 2.0 credits of German language instruction in consultation with department

cmCourseInfo.description: Continuing the work done in GER100Y1 and GER200Y1, this course offers German at the intermediate level focusing on extension of vocabulary, specific problems of grammar, essay-writing, reading and conversation. The Department reserves the right to place students in the appropriate course in the series GER200Y1 and GER300Y1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate German 2

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Since you are registering for GER300Y1 which is a Y (year) course you are expected to stay in the course for the full year.

Delivery Instructions

All GER300 courses are taught in person.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on contemporary German culture as expressed through a variety of media. It approaches Germany and Germany's position within Europe and the world mainly (but not exclusively) through non-literary texts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary German Culture and Media

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course is taught in German.

Pre-requisite: GER200Y/201H or placement test.

Students with prior knowledge of German may take the placement test. If placed beyond GER200Y, the prerequisite may be waived. To take the test, please email german.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca.

Open to students who are native German speakers.

courses.name: Weimar: Sex and Politics in the Roaring Twenties

cmCourseInfo.description: Focusing roughly on the period from 1918 to 1945, this course examines literary and artistic movements like Dada, Bauhaus, the Golden Age in German film in the decades between World War I and Nazism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Weimar: Sex and Politics in the Roaring Twenties

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course is taught in German.

Pre-requisite: GER205H or placement test.

Students with prior knowledge of German may take the placement test. If placed beyond GER300Y, the prerequisite may be waived. To take the test, please email german.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca.

Open to students who are native German speakers.

cmCourseInfo.description: This third-year course taught in German offers an in-depth exploration of diverse themes within German Studies, with a focus that varies from year to year. This course covers a wide range of topics, which may include contemporary issues in German-speaking societies, seminal German-language literary works, influential films, and philosophical movements.
cmCourseInfo.title: Open Topics in German Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

This course is taught in German.

Pre-requisite: GER205H or placement test.

 

Students with prior knowledge of German may take the placement test. If placed beyond GER300Y, the prerequisite may be waived. To take the test, please email german.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course investigates contemporary German culture by paying attention to its other or alternate voices and perspectives, i.e. those not usually prevalent in mainstream cultural and sociopolitical discourses.
cmCourseInfo.title: Post-Migrant Germany

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course is taught in German.

 

Pre-requisite: GER205H or placement test.

 

Students with prior knowledge of German may take the placement test. If placed beyond GER300Y, the prerequisite may be waived. To take the test, please email german.undergradadmin@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to Nietzsche, the philosopher, critic, and cultural theorist and examines the critically enduring significance of his legacy. Students will be familiarized with his critical contributions to epistemology, ethics, psychology, the theory of history, culture, and education as well as his impact on rethinking the agenda of philosophy. A particular aspect of the course will be the contextualization of his interventions in the intellectual landscape of his period and Nietzsche’s notoriously provocative writing style.
cmCourseInfo.title: Nietzsche

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course is taught in English. 
If you register for GER150HS you are required to take a tutorial if they are taking place.

courses.name: Topics in Yiddish or German Jewish Literature and Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: Topics in modern Yiddish or German Jewish literature and culture from the beginning of the 19th century to the present, featuring a selection of readings of modern Yiddish prose, poetry, drama and cinema. Taught in English and open to students across disciplines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Yiddish or German Jewish Literature and Culture [E]
